Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Frontiers in coding for cloud storage systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cloud storage systems increasingly form the backbone of software services that underwrite everyday lives, serving a large array of businesses and forming an essential pillar of the economy. Given the sheer volume of interactions within these distributed systems, there arise a multitude of issues in building, maintaining and enhancing them. The most salient of these challenges are in the reliability, availability, consistency, confidentiality and privacy of data stored in these vast systems.

The proposed research is expected to have a significant impact on the manner in which cloud storage systems are designed and deployed. In these systems, storage node failures can have a significant impact on the efficiency of the overall system. This project enhances fault tolerant mechanisms to enable efficient recovery from failures, while augmenting the overall data availability and privacy offered by such systems. The research effort will advance the science of cloud computing by developing a new family of algorithms for distributed storage , and connect the advances to the significant industry needs in this topic. The research agenda will also be tightly integrated with education and outreach activities with direct involvement of underrepresented minorities, graduate, and undergraduate students.

Focusing on efficient maintenance of data with a range of desirable qualities, including mechanisms that ease data encoding, accessibility, updates, as well as privacy, the main objectives of this effort include (i) to develop coding schemes where a failed element can be regenerated with higher repair efficiencies from its local neighbors, (ii) to bring together the advantages of both local decodability and local repairability into one coding solution, (iii) to design mechanisms that provide low cost data updates in addition to efficient repair, (iv) to develop codes that can be resilient against failures with different scales/modalities, (v) to develop coding mechanisms taking advantage of implementation aspects of existing systems, and (vi) to develop coding schemes that enable users to access their data in a private manner. This effort addresses these challenges using a combination of tools from disciplines spanning coding theory, information theory, communications, as well as combinatorial and discrete mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Distribute storage and computing systems form the backbone of cloud services that we depend on in our everyday lives. Given the volume of interactions within these systems, there are variety of issues in building and maintaining them. This project developed novel techniques to improve reliability, availability, consistency, confidentiality and privacy of these systems. 


The project brought together ideas from different domains in computer science, electrical and computer engineering, including coding theory, information theory, security, and networking, and trained graduate and postdoctoral students in these domains, supporting the educational efforts and generation of the new workforce in information technologies. In particular, the project led to the following developments.


a) We formulated new frameworks to analyze these distributed systems. One of our efforts is the centralized node repair framework, which focuses on a server recovering data stored in multiple storage nodes. We have characterized the fundamental limits for this problem (for the case where nodes operate at minimum storage), and derived performance bounds for other scenarios, analyzing the gap to optimality for our schemes.


b) We have constructed a relationship between privacy preserving information retrieval and coding systems that allow local node recovery. Bringing these two problems together allowed us to use results of one for the other. This led to better understanding of these problems, e.g., developing new fundamental limits. In addition, this connection allowed two different domains to cross paths and opened doors for further developments in these areas.


c) We developed techniques that lower the communication bandwidth in the presence of node failures. One of the results we achieved in this direction was the development of optimal high rate MDS codes that enable bandwidth efficient node recovery through low complexity codes (having polynomial sub-packetization). This effort broadens the set of cases where we know optimal code constructions.


d) We utilized combinatorial designs and other coding techniques to mitigate adversarial stragglers in distributed learning. In this context, we have developed schemed that can optimally trade-off between computation load per worker, communication overhead per worker, and straggler tolerance. In particular, the techniques we developed have smaller decoding complexity and higher numerical stability as compared to prior works, and improve latency of machine learning iterations.
